subject: Aerospace Engineering
question_text:
The following system of linear equations
7x - 3y + z = 0
3x - y + z = 0
x - y - z = 0
has:
question_text_latex:
The following system of linear equations
$7x - 3y + z = 0$
$3x - y + z = 0$
$x - y - z = 0$
has:

tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: The question requires solving a system of linear equations to determine the nature of the solutions. It involves numerical calculation (solving the system) and multi-step reasoning to determine if the solution is unique, infinite, or non-existent. The difficulty is moderate as it requires knowledge of linear algebra.

answer_validation.reasoning:
The given system of linear equations is a homogeneous system ($Ax = 0$) because all constant terms are zero. A homogeneous system is always consistent, meaning it always has at least the trivial solution ($x=0, y=0, z=0$). To determine if there are infinitely many solutions or only the trivial solution, we examine the determinant of the coefficient matrix $A$.

The coefficient matrix is:
$$A = \begin{pmatrix} 7 & -3 & 1 \\ 3 & -1 & 1 \\ 1 & -1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}$$

Calculate the determinant of $A$:
$$\det(A) = 7 \left( (-1)(-1) - (1)(-1) \right) - (-3) \left( (3)(-1) - (1)(1) \right) + 1 \left( (3)(-1) - (-1)(1) \right)$$
$$\det(A) = 7(1 + 1) + 3(-3 - 1) + 1(-3 + 1)$$
$$\det(A) = 7(2) + 3(-4) + 1(-2)$$
$$\det(A) = 14 - 12 - 2$$
$$\det(A) = 0$$

Since $\det(A) = 0$, the rank of the coefficient matrix $A$ is less than the number of unknowns (which is 3). For a homogeneous system, if $\det(A) = 0$ (or equivalently, if $\text{rank}(A) < \text{number of unknowns}$), the system has infinitely many solutions. Therefore, the system has infinitely many solutions.

step_by_step: Step 1: Identify the system type. Recognize that the given system of linear equations (7x - 3y + z = 0, 3x - y + z = 0, x - y - z = 0) is a homogeneous system because all constant terms on the right-hand side are zero. Homogeneous systems always have at least the trivial solution (x=0, y=0, z=0).

Step 2: Form the coefficient matrix. Write the coefficient matrix A from the given equations:
A = [[7, -3, 1],
     [3, -1, 1],
     [1, -1, -1]]

Step 3: Calculate the determinant of A. Compute the determinant of A to check for linear independence and the nature of solutions.
det(A) = 7((-1)(-1) - (1)(-1)) - (-3)(3(-1) - 1(1)) + 1(3(-1) - (-1)(1))
       = 7(1 + 1) + 3(-3 - 1) + 1(-3 + 1)
       = 7(2) + 3(-4) + 1(-2)
       = 14 - 12 - 2
       = 0

Step 4: Interpret the determinant. Since det(A) = 0, the rows (and columns) of the matrix are linearly dependent. For a homogeneous system, a determinant of zero implies that there are infinitely many non-trivial solutions, in addition to the trivial solution.

Step 5: Determine the rank of A using Gaussian elimination. To confirm the number of independent solutions, perform row operations on the augmented matrix [A|0] (or just A, as the right-hand side remains zero for homogeneous systems).
Start with:
[[7, -3, 1],
 [3, -1, 1],
 [1, -1, -1]]

Step 7: Continue row reduction.
R3 -> R3 - 2R2:
[[1, -1, -1],
 [0, 2, 4],
 [0, 0, 0]]
Step 8: Identify the rank. The row echelon form has two non-zero rows. Therefore, the rank of the coefficient matrix A, denoted as rank(A), is 2.

Step 9: Compare rank with the number of unknowns. The number of unknowns (n) is 3 (x, y, z). Since rank(A) = 2, which is less than n = 3, the system has infinitely many solutions. (For a homogeneous system, rank(A) = rank([A|0]) is always true, so the condition rank(A) = rank([A|b]) < n simplifies to rank(A) < n).
formulas_used: For $Ax = 0$, unique solution iff $\det(A) \neq 0$ (trivial only). Infinite solutions iff $\det(A) = 0$ and system consistent (always true for homogeneous).
General condition: For $Ax = b$, consistent if $\text{rank}(A) = \text{rank}([A|b])$. Then: unique solution if rank = n; infinite solutions if rank < n.

essential: Concept of rank of a matrix
helpful: Null space and dimension of solution set

Nature of Solutions for Linear Systems: requires: Understanding of consistency (existence of solution)
requires: Rank of matrix and augmented matrix
enables: Analysis of equilibrium equations in structures
enables: Solving control system state equations
Main Concept: enables: Solving Engineering Problems with Multiple Variables

difficulty_factors: Requires knowing homogeneous systems are always consistent
Requires accurate determinant calculation or row reduction

textbook_references.author: B.S. Grewal
textbook_references.text_snippet: A system of linear equations is consistent if it has at least one solution. For homogeneous systems, always consistent. Infinite solutions if rank of coefficient matrix less than number of unknowns.

textbook_references.author: Erwin Kreyszig
textbook_references.chapter_title: Linear Algebra: Matrices, Vectors, Determinants. Systems of Linear Equations.
textbook_references.specific_concept: Consistency of System of Linear Equations
textbook_references.text_snippet: The nature of the solutions of a system of linear equations is determined by the rank of the coefficient matrix A and the rank of the augmented matrix [A|b].

video_references.topic_covered: System of Linear Equations, infinite solutions (coincident lines)
Conditions for unique, no, or infinite solutions using determinant and rank

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Check homogeneity → Compute determinant → If zero, find rank via row reduction → Compare rank with number of unknowns.
key_insights: Homogeneous systems are always consistent, so only need to check if solution is unique or infinite.
det(A)=0 immediately rules out unique solution, but must confirm rank to distinguish between no solution (impossible here) and infinite solutions.
Rank gives the number of independent equations; free variables = n - rank.

formulas_principles.name: Determinant Condition for Linear Dependence
formulas_principles.conditions: For a square matrix A, det(A)=0 indicates rows/columns are linearly dependent. For a homogeneous system Ax=0, if this condition is met, the system has infinitely many solutions.
formulas_principles.relevance: First test to rule out unique solution and a core principle for solving this problem.

formulas_principles.name: Condition for Infinite Solutions
formulas_principles.conditions: For a consistent system Ax=b with n unknowns, if rank of the coefficient matrix equals rank of the augmented matrix but is less than the number of unknowns, there are infinitely many solutions. For homogeneous systems, consistency is always guaranteed, so the condition simplifies to rank(A) < n.
formulas_principles.relevance: Core condition used to conclude infinite solutions when the determinant is zero.

industry_examples: Solving for forces in statically indeterminate truss structures (civil/aerospace structures)
Finding equilibrium states in control system analysis (state-space representation)
Control system design (e.g., analyzing the stability and response of linear dynamic systems).
specific_systems: Finite element method for structural analysis
Stability analysis of aircraft longitudinal dynamics
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Determining if a physical system described by linear equations has a unique equilibrium or multiple possible states is crucial for design and analysis. Understanding the nature of solutions (unique, infinite, or no solution) is vital for designing stable, predictable, and feasible systems, as infinite solutions can indicate redundancy or an under-constrained design, while no solution suggests an impossible design or a contradiction.

common_mistakes.mistake: Assuming det(A)=0 implies no solution (forgetting homogeneous systems are always consistent).
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Confusing homogeneous (b=0) with non-homogeneous systems where det(A)=0 could lead to no solution or infinite solutions.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always note the right-hand side: if all zeros, it's homogeneous and always consistent. det(A)=0 means either infinite solutions or (for homogeneous) only infinite solutions (since trivial solution exists). Additionally, practice determinant and rank calculations regularly to avoid general errors.

common_mistakes.mistake: Arithmetic errors in calculating determinant or during row reduction.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Rushing under exam pressure, misplacing signs, or incorrect multiplication.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Perform steps carefully, double-check arithmetic. For determinant, use systematic expansion. For row reduction, write each step clearly. Additionally, carefully review the conditions for each solution type.
common_mistakes.consequence: Incorrect rank calculation, leading to wrong conclusion.

common_mistakes.mistake: Thinking that number of equations equals number of unknowns (3) guarantees a unique solution.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Over-simplification from early algebra where 3 equations 3 unknowns often yield unique solution.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember that linear dependence among equations can reduce effective number of independent equations, determined by rank.

common_mistakes.mistake: Misinterpreting 'infinitely many solutions' as 'three solutions' (option D).
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Option D is a distractor; some might think because there are three variables, there could be three specific solutions.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Understand that 'infinitely many' means a continuum of solutions, often expressed parametrically (e.g., with free variable t).

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: HITS: Homogeneous, Infinite if det=0, Trivial always, Search for rank.
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Recall behavior of homogeneous systems: always have trivial solution; if determinant zero, infinite solutions; check rank to confirm.

flashcards.front: For a homogeneous system Ax=0, what are the possible solution types?
flashcards.back: Always consistent. Either unique solution (trivial, x=0) if det(A) ≠ 0 (rank = n), or infinitely many solutions if det(A) = 0 (rank < n).

flashcards.front: State the condition for infinite solutions in a consistent linear system Ax=b.
flashcards.back: rank(A) = rank([A|b]) < n, where n is number of unknowns. Equivalently, number of free variables = n - rank(A) > 0.

flashcards.front: If det(A)=0 for a homogeneous system, what can you conclude?
flashcards.back: The system has infinitely many solutions (including the trivial solution). It never has 'no solution' because homogeneous systems are always consistent.

flashcards.front: How would you quickly determine the nature of solutions for a 3x3 homogeneous system?
flashcards.back: Compute determinant of coefficient matrix. If non-zero -> unique (trivial) solution. If zero -> infinitely many solutions (rank < 3).

real_world_context.industry_example: Solving for internal forces in a statically indeterminate truss (e.g., aircraft wing spar). The equilibrium equations form a homogeneous system when external loads are zero. Infinite solutions indicate multiple possible internal stress distributions, requiring compatibility conditions.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Designing safe structures requires understanding if loads can be uniquely determined or if additional constraints are needed.

real_world_context.industry_example: Finding the equilibrium points of a linear state-space model: dx/dt = Ax. Setting dx/dt=0 gives Ax=0. Infinite solutions imply a line or plane of equilibrium points, affecting stability analysis.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Determines the system's steady-state behavior and controllability.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Quick check: homogeneous system -> always consistent. Compute determinant mentally or with simple arithmetic. If zero, answer is infinite solutions. If non-zero, unique trivial solution. This is a fast 1-minute question.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If short on time, note that for homogeneous systems with det=0, the answer is always 'infinitely many solutions'. Option D ('three solutions') is almost never correct in linear algebra.
exam_strategy.time_management: Allocate 1-2 minutes. If determinant calculation seems messy, skip to row reduction quickly or guess based on linear dependence observation.

search_keywords: GATE AE engineering mathematics linear algebra

alternative_methods.name: Eigenvalue Analysis
alternative_methods.description: For homogeneous system Ax=0, non-trivial solutions exist if 0 is an eigenvalue of A. That is, if A is singular (det(A)=0). This is equivalent to the determinant condition.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Connects to deeper linear algebra concepts. Cons: Overkill for this problem; requires computing eigenvalues.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: When analyzing solution structure in relation to eigenvectors.

alternative_methods.name: Vector Cross Product Check (for 3 equations, 3 unknowns)
alternative_methods.description: If each equation is viewed as a plane through origin, infinite solutions occur if the normals are coplanar. Check if scalar triple product of normals is zero.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Geometric intuition. Cons: Only works for 3D; similar to determinant of coefficient matrix.

connections_to_other_subjects.Structures: Equilibrium equations in statics often lead to homogeneous systems when no external loads; infinite solutions indicate static indeterminacy.
connections_to_other_subjects.Flight Mechanics: Linearized equations of motion about an equilibrium can be homogeneous; infinite solutions correspond to neutral stability modes.
connections_to_other_subjects.Control Systems: State-space models: dx/dt = Ax has equilibrium at x=0; infinite solutions imply non-isolated equilibria.
connections_to_other_subjects.Fluid Dynamics: Discretization of governing equations (like Navier-Stokes) in Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) leads to large sparse linear systems that need to be solved numerically.
connections_to_other_subjects.Mathematics: This problem involves core concepts from linear algebra, which is a fundamental subject in mathematics and underpins many areas of engineering.

deeper_dive_topics: Null Space (Kernel) of a matrix: The set of all solutions to Ax=0. Dimension = n - rank(A).
Parametric representation of infinite solutions: express basic variables in terms of free variables.
Relationship to rank-nullity theorem: rank(A) + nullity(A) = n.
Linear Dependence and Independence of Vectors
